title: Erdogan Rebuffs U.S. Call to Protect Kurds
summary: Turkish president says national security adviser John Bolton 'made a serious mistake,' threatens new offensive against key force fighting Islamic State. President Trump's plans for a swift withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria were thrown into disarray when Turkey's president rejected a request to protect U.S. allies fighting in the region and instead threatened military strikes against them.

title: U.S. Signals Off-Ramp for Sanctions Against Venezuelan TV Station
summary: Treasury increasingly using strategy to separate sanctions targets from investments. The U.S. signaled a Venezuelan media giant can get off the sanctions list if it sheds its owner-a tactic the U.S. increasingly is using to disentangle what it considers bad actors from the companies they own.

title: Cuomo's Talk of Tearing Up MTA Timed to Upcoming Budget Season
summary: Governor will work with state legislators to hammer out deal that could provide billions of dollars for troubled agency. Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to overhaul the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Courts!
summary: 'We've lost everything, including the right to free and fair elections.'. Slate's Dahlia Lilthwick in a symposium on "what the world will look like in 20 years," NYMag.com, Jan. 6:

title: Lawmakers Grill Murphy Officials Over Handling of Assault Claim
summary: New Jersey governor's lawyer, deputy counsel are asked why they didn't do more for accuser. TRENTON, N.J.-New Jersey lawmakers on Tuesday grilled officials in Gov. Phil Murphy's campaign, transition team and administration over their handling of a sexual-assault allegation against a state employee, repeatedly circling back to one question: Should they have done more?

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Mysterious Foreign Company
summary: High court upholds order that unnamed company can't skirt penalties on sovereign-immunity grounds. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court Tuesday rejected an unnamed foreign company's effort to avoid penalties for defying a grand jury subpoena that appears to be part of special counsel Robert Mueller's inquiry into Russian electoral interference.

title: Departures Resume From London Heathrow Following Drone Sighting
summary: Episode follows similar disruption in December at nearby Gatwick Airport. LONDON-Heathrow Airport, one of the world's busiest international aviation hubs, temporarily halted departing flights late Tuesday after a nearby drone sighting, the second closing of a London airport due to drones in less than three weeks.

title: The U.S. Has Always Chosen World Bank Presidents-Will It This Time?
summary: Consensus was already fraying around the U.S. role when outgoing President Jim Yong Kim was selected in 2012. The U.S. has always chosen the president of the World Bank. This time it may not go that way, with the unexpected resignation of its president, Jim Yong Kim, announced Monday.

title: Blackstone-Backed Exeter Finance Files for IPO
summary: Resume Subscription. Blackstone Group LP-backed Exeter Finance Corp. has filed preliminary documents for an initial public offering.

title: Democrats Introduce Bill Expanding Background Checks on Gun Sales
summary: Legislation will likely pass the House later this year but is expected to stall in the GOP-led Senate. Democrats said their long-pledged push to tighten the country's gun laws would take center stage early this year as lawmakers introduced legislation Tuesday aimed at expanding background checks to nearly all gun sales.

title: The 380,000
summary: Just how many unnecessary employees does the federal government employ?. This column doesn't wish to seem hard-hearted but feels obliged to ask the various parties negotiating an end to the partial government shutdown why the affected agencies have been employing nearly twice as many workers as they deem necessary to fulfill their missions. Whether President Donald Trump, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer decide to call structures at the border walls or fences, they ought to at least explain how they are managing the public payroll inside the United States.

title: Ethics and Campaign Reforms on Horizon in Albany
summary: With an all-Democratic government in Albany, new ethics-enforcement measures including a new enforcement agency could become law. New York government-reform advocates say they are more optimistic than ever for the passage of state laws tightening ethics enforcement, easing voting restrictions and restricting campaign finance contributions with an all-Democratic government convening this year in Albany.

title: Biotech Proposes Paying for Pricey Drugs by Installment
summary: Bluebird Bio develops plan to sell gene-replacement therapy with annual payments contingent on continued effectiveness. A Boston-area biotech says it may have a found a way to handle the expected seven-figure cost of its experimental gene therapy: paying on installment.

title: Stocks Advance for a Third Session
summary: Gains in S&P 500 led by trade-sensitive industrial stocks with exposure to Chinese economy. Signs of progress between the U.S. and China on trade negotiations propelled U.S. stocks higher Tuesday, their third consecutive session of gains.

title: 'Fritz Ascher: Expressionist' Review: Finally at Home With the Greats
summary: An exhibition at the Grey Art Gallery places the under-the-radar Ascher squarely in the canon of 20th-century German artists.. New York

title: Dollar Climbs as Investors Reconsider Rate Outlook
summary: Powell's comments last week bolster investor confidence. The dollar ticked higher Tuesday, showing tentative signs of stabilizing after Federal Reserve Jerome Powell's comments last week bolstered investors' confidence that the Fed will be cautious about raising interest rates this year.

title: PG&E Replaces Head of Electric System
summary: Departure comes as utility's shares dropped again due to concerns about its financial health. PG&E Corp.'s top executive overseeing the utility's electric division is leaving the company amid rising concerns about its financial health and safety practices following the recent California wildfires.

title: 'Aeonic' by Balsam Range Review: Bluegrass That's Ready to Grow
summary: The eclectic group from North Carolina proves it could leap to great popularity with an album that blends deep musical traditions with modern touches..

title: U.S. Carbon Emissions Rose 3.4% in 2018 as Economy Surged
summary: Nation's sharp reductions of greenhouse gases in recent years might be coming to an end. U.S. carbon emissions rose 3.4% in 2018, after three years of declines, as the effects of a strong economy outstripped a sharp decline in the number of power plants burning coal to generate electricity.

title: A Journey With Lung Cancer
summary: Twelve years-and a world of difference-between bouts for one patient and her family. Two years ago, at the age of 55, Terri Ann DiJulio was diagnosed with lung cancer-for the second time.

title: Kavanaugh Delivers First Opinion as Ginsburg Is Absent
summary: The new justice wrote for a unanimous bench in an arbitration dispute as his fellow justice recuperated from cancer surgery. WASHINGTON-Shades of the past and future permeated Supreme Court proceedings on Tuesday, as Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's chair remained vacant while she recuperates from cancer treatment, and new Justice Brett Kavanaugh delivered his first opinion.

title: Oil Extends Rebound as Oversupply Fears Ease
summary: Supply curbs from large producers and improved risk appetite with stocks bouncing back have boosted crude. • Oil prices climbed for the seventh consecutive session, extending a recent rebound to start 2019 as oversupply fears continued to ease. Supply curbs from large producers and improved risk appetite with stocks also bouncing back from punishing fourth-quarter declines have boosted crude. The winning streak is its longest since July.

title: Entry Exam to City's Top High Schools Underrates Girls, Study Finds
summary: Researcher says admissions test for New York City's elite public schools doesn't capture girls' potential. New York City's eight specialized public high schools have long accepted fewer girls than boys. A study drawing new attention to that disparity finds the entry exam underestimates girls' academic success.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Fall Amid Auctions
summary: Investor fear seen to abate as Treasury note offering brings modest demand. U.S. government bond prices fell Tuesday amid signs that risk sentiment is improving while the Treasury Department completed the first of three auctions this week.

title: Manafort Lawyers Reveal New Details of His Links to Kiev Associate
summary: Disclosures come in filing playing down ex-Trump campaign chief's alleged lies to Mueller investigators. Attorneys for Paul Manafort inadvertently disclosed on Tuesday that the former Trump campaign chairman gave 2016 presidential polling data to a Kiev associate U.S. officials have linked to Russian intelligence and may have discussed a Ukraine peace plan with him.

title: New York City to Offer More Health Care to the Uninsured
summary: The new plan will give access to primary care and other preventive services. New York City will spend about $100 million a year to expand health care to the city's uninsured and undocumented residents by giving them access to primary-care physicians and other preventive-care services, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Tuesday.

title: Small-Cap Stocks Take On New Shine
summary: Profits across the Russell 2000 are seen growing nearly 16% in quarter, far outpacing earnings growth for S&P 500 firms. Small-capitalization companies are projected to notch another year of big profit gains, potentially making their shares a haven for investors as earnings at larger firms slow.

title: Eddie Lampert Wants to Save Sears But Mall Owners Say Don't Bother
summary: Many landlords have lost faith in the company's chairman and say the department store's brand is outdated. Shopping center owners usually dread the prospect of a big retail operator shutting its doors. In the case of Sears Holdings Corp., many landlords are welcoming it.

title: Baltimore Mayor Picks New Orleans's Police Chief to Lead Troubled Force
summary: Big Easy recorded fewest homicides since 1971 under Michael Harrison's watch. BALTIMORE-Baltimore's mayor on Tuesday nominated New Orleans's top cop to run the city's troubled police department, a day after the withdrawal of her first pick brought fresh upheaval in one of the nation's most violent cities.

title: Boeing, Airbus Miss 2018 Jet Delivery Targets
summary: Plane makers hit record outputs but are still straining to meet booming global demand for air travel. Boeing Co. and Airbus SE failed to deliver all the jets they had once planned to make in 2018, showing how production problems are holding back the two top plane makers as demand for airliners soars.

title: Zuckerberg's Personal 2019 Challenge: Talk More About Tech's Problems
summary: Facebook CEO to host public discussions on role of technology in society. Mark Zuckerberg last year boldly announced his personal challenge was to fix Facebook . This year the Facebook CEO and founder is setting a more modest goal.

title: Dotdash, Riding Wave of Search Traffic, Acquires New Sites
summary: The publisher, which owns sites including The Spruce and Verywell, is buying two beauty websites as annual revenue passes $100 million.

title: Global Growth to Lose Momentum This Year, World Bank Says
summary: Bank lowers estimate for global growth to 2.9% in 2018, citing trade tension and other challenges. The World Bank cut its forecasts for global growth in 2019 and 2020, citing a worsening set of factors from trade tensions to financial-market instability to currency challenges in a number of emerging markets.

title: Canadian Truck Driver Pleads Guilty in Deadly Hockey Bus Crash
summary: April 2018 accident killed 16, shocked North American hockey community. OTTAWA-The truck driver involved in a deadly crash last year with a bus carrying members of a rural Canadian junior hockey team pleaded guilty on Tuesday to all of the charges against him.

title: The Drug Price-Control Threat
summary: Trump, Sanders and Warren sound the same themes. Watch out.. For all the nasty partisan divisiveness in Washington, it's often worth worrying more when both parties agree. A case in point is a potential left-right condominium on drug prices that should alarm Americans hoping a cure for cancer or Alzheimer's arrives in their lifetime.

title: Cancer Deaths Decline 27% Over 25 Years
summary: Improvement reflects reduced smoking but obesity could influence future projections. Deaths from cancer dropped 27% over a quarter century, meaning an estimated 2.6 million fewer people died of the disease during that period, according to a new report from researchers at the American Cancer Society.

title: U.S. Sanctions Aim to Pressure Venezuela's Maduro
summary: Treasury penalizes ex-officials it says perpetrated a huge fraud in Venezuela's currency markets, days before the leftist leader starts a second term. The U.S. Treasury Department on Tuesday sanctioned a Venezuelan network that allowed the owner of media giant Globovision Tele C.A. and several state-connected businesspeople to illicitly make billions of dollars in profits from the country's broken currency market.

title: The Saints Already Thrashed the Eagles. Will the Playoffs Be More of the Same?
summary: After losing to New Orleans 48-7 in the regular season, Philadelphia faces long odds in the rematch. One of the NFL's most debated topics heading into this weekend's divisional playoff games is whether the Philadelphia Eagles are better off with Nick Foles or Carson Wentz at quarterback. Filling in for an injured Wentz last season, Foles led the Eagles on a playoff run that culminated in a Super Bowl victory. Then in December, after Wentz was sidelined with a back injury, Foles once again rescued the season. leading the team into the playoffs and rallying Philadelphia to a wild-card game win in Chicago.

title: Costly iPhone Canary and a U.S.-China Rift
summary: Can and should trade relations with China be divorced from U.S. national security and other noneconomic interests?. Your Jan. 4 editorial "The iPhone Canary" notes "the interdependence of the U.S. and Chinese economies" and that "the two countries' economies are entwined for better or worse." While it may have been President Richard Nixon who "opened" China to the West, it was President George H.W. Bush, the former chief liaison from Washington to the People's Republic, who initiated a policy of interdependence between the two economies. Trade with China and its integration into international institutions have been tremendously successful in reducing tensions between the two countries for nearly 30 years. We're currently witnessing a severe test of the strength of this bond.

title: Infrastructure Needs Meet the Pork Barrel
summary: Congress and the Trump administration should address the Highway Trust Fund, the airport passenger facility charge and the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund.. Regarding your editorial "You Call That 'Infrastructure'?" (Jan. 4): The American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) is encouraged that both President Trump and the new House majority have signaled that infrastructure is an area for bipartisanship. The desire exists within the legislative and executive branches, and now it is time to put that desire into action.

title: Australia Weighing Asylum for Saudi Teen Who Fled Family
summary: Rahaf Mohammed Alqunun barricaded herself in a Thailand airport hotel room, took to social media. Australia's government has promised to consider any application for asylum from the young Saudi woman who barricaded herself in a transit hotel at Bangkok's international airport and said her family would kill her if she returned home.

title: Harvey Weinstein's Trial Set to Begin in Early May
summary: Former Hollywood producer has pleaded not guilty to charges of rape, other sex crimes. Former Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein is scheduled to go to trial on sex-crime charges May 6 in state court in Manhattan, court filings show.

title: Beijing's Curious Silence on the Syria Withdrawal
summary: For all its bluster, China relies on the U.S.-led international order to secure its own interests.. One of the more troubling yardsticks by which to measure President Trump's decision to withdraw U.S. forces from Syria was the gratification it seemed to offer American adversaries.

title: EU Imposes Fresh Sanctions on Iran Over Assassination Plots
summary: The bloc faces conflicting pressures as it tries to salvage its nuclear deal while confronting hostile behavior in the region. BRUSSELS-The European Union imposed its first sanctions against Iran since the nuclear accord was implemented three years ago, as European diplomats warned their Iranian counterparts that the bloc wouldn't tolerate further alleged Iranian attacks and assassinations in Europe.

title: China Approves DowDuPont's Genetically Modified Soybeans
summary: Approval is given to DowDuPont soybean that is genetically modified to survive powerful herbicide combination. China's approval of new genetically engineered crops will open a new front in U.S. farmers' long-running war against hard-to-kill weeds.

title: Russian Lawyer Charged With Obstruction of Justice
summary: Natalya Veselnitskaya, who met with Trump campaign officials in 2016, is charged in unrelated case. The Russian lawyer who met with Trump campaign officials at Trump Tower in 2016 has been charged with obstruction of justice stemming from her role in a federal money-laundering case, according to an indictment unsealed Tuesday in Manhattan federal court.

title: Verizon Adds Subscribers as Device Makers Struggle
summary: The carrier added more customers than analysts expected in the fourth quarter. Verizon Communications Inc. continued to expand its base of wireless phone subscribers in the final quarter of 2018, a period in which smartphone makers Apple Inc. and Samsung Electronics Co. have warned investors they would fall short of expectations.

title: Bank of Canada Expected to Keep Rates on Hold Amid Lower Crude Prices
summary: Wednesday's decision is likely to shed more light on how heavily cheaper energy will weigh on GDP. OTTAWA-The Bank of Canada is widely expected to keep its benchmark overnight interest rate on hold at a policy announcement Wednesday, giving officials more time to monitor the impact of low oil prices and financial-market turbulence on the Canadian economy.

title: Should Rugs Stay Out of the Kitchen? Designers Duke it Out
summary: Some interior designers think the kitchen is no place for a crumb-catching carpet. Others believe they can work around the ick factor.. FROM A PRACTICAL standpoint, many people greet the notion of a rug in the kitchen with a visceral response: Ick. "I can't imagine anything less appetizing than something that absorbs smells, soaks up spills and holds footprints on the floor of an environment that is meant to be clean, beautiful and functional," said bicoastal designer Tim Campbell. Some also question the wisdom of introducing a potential skateboard-a textile apt to slip across a slick floor-into the room. Rug-averse Toronto designer Anne Hepfer finds other, safer ways to add a layer of design, texture and color. "I love using tiles and custom vinyl runners in kitchens," she said. Her favorite source of the latter, Bolon, creates a sustainable version by converting vinyl waste, she said. Minimalists such as Mr. Campbell villainize rugs in the kitchen as clutter, while Houston designer Margaret Naeve, a fan of natural stone and herringbone-wood floors, sees them as interlopers that interfere with the room's aesthetic: "The kitchen is a place to mix finishes into the overall design," she said. "Why cover it up with a rug?"

title: The Psychiatrist Can See Your Child Now, Virtually
summary: With a growing shortage of mental-health professionals for children and adolescents, more health-care providers are turning to technology.

title: Facebook, Twitter Turn to Right-Leaning Groups to Help Referee Political Speech
summary: Resume Subscription. The world's biggest social-media companies, under fire for failing to police content on their sites, have invited an array of outside groups to help them figure out who should be banned and what's considered unacceptable.

title: WeWork Raises Additional Capital From SoftBank
summary: The co-working space provider secures an additional $2 billion and says it is rebranding itself as the We Company. WeWork Cos. secured an additional $2 billion from SoftBank Group Corp. , a smaller amount than the Japanese company had previously planned to invest in the co-working space provider.

title: Microsoft's Brief Comeback
summary: Amazon.com took the crown as world's most valuable company Monday with about $797 billion in market value versus $784 billion for Microsoft. Microsoft 's return as the world's most valuable company was short. But in the current market, Amazon.com shouldn't get too comfortable either.

title: Carlos Ghosn's Lawyer Launches Campaign to Clear His Client
summary: The lead defense attorney for the former Nissan chairman said he hoped to speed up Ghosn's release on bail. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn's lawyer took aim at Japanese prosecutors Tuesday, arguing that they rushed to judgment and had no basis for their lengthy detention of the auto executive.

title: Are Those Gold Teeth or Did You Just Eat in the Gaudiest Place on Earth?
summary: An edible-gold arms race is on in the United Arab Emirates, and the upscale treats can be a mess to eat. 'I had gold all over my teeth and my mouth.'. DUBAI-Bill Riththilertnapa ordered a $26 cappuccino topped with a sheaf of 23-karat gold with his wife and parents at the Armani Hotel here last January for one reason: Instagram.

title: Saudi Arabia Edges Toward Bet on Booming U.S. Energy Sector
summary: Aramco's potential deal to invest in U.S. liquefied natural gas projects would mark a sea change in the energy flows between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia is nearing a deal to invest in U.S. liquefied natural gas, a landmark decision for the kingdom, which in the past had been a huge supplier of energy to America.

title: U.S. Job Openings Fell in November
summary: Layoffs edged higher in the month, Labor Department says. The number of unfilled jobs in the U.S. fell in November to the lowest level since June, though openings still exceeded unemployed Americans.

title: MetLife CEO Steven Kandarian to Retire in April
summary: Top lieutenant Michel Khalaf to succeed Kandarian as president and chief executive. MetLife Inc. President and Chief Executive Steven Kandarian is turning over the reins of the nation's second-biggest life insurer by assets to a top lieutenant, Michel Khalaf, as he sets April 30 for his retirement.

title: Workforce-Training Program Shares Secret to Students' Success: Grit
summary: Initiative blends job training (in fields such as financial services) with life training (how to shake hands). If Ridmi Coe shows up late for her workplace-training program, Year Up New York, she gets a 15-point penalty. If she swears, uses her cellphone or doesn't dress professionally, same thing. If her score falls below zero, she's expelled from the free program.

title: Apple's Answer to Slower iPhone Sales? The Trade In
summary: The tech giant is pushing a program that often pays more than carriers do to persuade people to exchange older devices; touting a $449 iPhone XR. Wireless carriers have long made smartphones look cheaper to consumers by subsidizing their cost. Now Apple Inc. is trying to woo phone buyers, offsetting the price of devices with generous trade-in offers.

title: What's Up With Men Who Don't Wear Coats in Winter?
summary: You've seen them: those stubborn guys who refuse to dress appropriately for the weather. We attempt to understand their 'reasoning'. EVERY WINTER, the season's most confounding species emerges: the Male Nojacketus. On that first freezing day, you can spot him standing on the subway platform or hoofing it to Starbucks, nonchalant in his meager button-up shirt. Even when this foolhardy creature can see his own breath, he may not don a coat, or even a pair of pants (Male Nojacketi adore shorts, especially of the cargo variety). Scarfs or gloves? He would never stoop to such compromising accessories. The most extreme variety of the species will bare his toes in flip-flops on days that could easily end in snow.

title: Itzhak Perlman Became a Star on TV at Age 13
summary: The violinist and conductor beat postwar poverty in Israel to become a 16-time Grammy winner and Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient. Itzhak Perlman, 73, is a violinist, conductor and educator who won 16 Grammys and was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015. He is the subject of the 2017 documentary, "Itzhak," directed by Alison Chernick. He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Germany Shows Symptoms of Deeper Economic Pain
summary: Europe's biggest economy posts more disappointing data, boding ill for the wider economy. FRANKFURT-Fresh signs of a weakening German economy are raising fears that last year's slowdown could spill into 2019, deepening the challenges facing policy makers in Europe and the U.S.

title: Mattel Plans Live-Action Barbie Film
summary: Toy company working with Warner Bros. to develop the film; Margot Robbie cast to play Barbie character. Mattel Inc. wants to return Barbie to the big screen and plans to create the first live-action feature film starring the character from its iconic toy franchise.

title: AmEx Suspends a Director in Foreign-Exchange Pricing Probe
summary: Employees were informed that Taylor Simonin was suspended last month. American Express Co. suspended a director in its foreign-exchange department as part of its ongoing investigation into pricing practices in the division, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Emily Blunt and John Krasinski Buy One of Brooklyn's Priciest Properties
summary: The actors purchased two adjacent units in a Brooklyn Heights building where Matt Damon bought a penthouse for a record price. Actors Emily Blunt and John Krasinski paid about $11 million for a full floor in a luxury Brooklyn condominium building, according to people familiar with the deal. The transaction is one of the largest ever done in the New York City borough, public records show.

title: U.S., China Narrow Differences on Trade
summary: Progress made on issues including purchases of U.S. goods and services. BEIJING-The U.S. and China made progress on narrowing their differences on trade issues, especially on purchases of U.S. goods and services and widening access to China's markets, though the two sides are far from striking a deal.

title: Hulu Reports More Than 25 Million Subscribers in 2018
summary: Streaming service says its subscriber total rose 48%, still much smaller than Netflix's. Hulu had more than 25 million subscribers at the end of 2018, up by eight million from the year earlier, the streaming service announced Tuesday.

title: The 16 Best Denim Looks for Him and Her
Billionaire Henry Kravis Asks $46 Million for Colorado Ranch
summary: The KKR co-founder is selling a property with a Greg Norman-designed golf course and helipad that is located more than an hour from Aspen. Henry R. Kravis, the billionaire co-founder of private equity giant KKR , is putting his luxurious Colorado ranch on the market for $46 million.

title: How Clemson Emulated Silicon Valley to Win a National Title
summary: Just as the technology business became known for the relative youth of its executives-valuing skill over experience-Clemson typifies college football's growing embrace of freshman quarterbacks. SANTA CLARA, Calif.-The day before he won the national championship, Clemson quarterback Trevor Lawrence was reminded of an anniversary of sorts. Tigers quarterbacks coach Brandon Streeter told him Sunday marked one year to the day that he arrived on campus, just a few weeks after graduating from high school.

title: Nissan Needs a New Carlos Ghosn
summary: The Japanese carmaker will be harder to turn around now that it is enmeshed in a global alliance. Carlos Ghosn won his spurs turning Nissan around in the early 2000s. Now the Japanese car maker needs an even more sophisticated turnaround artist.

title: Jazz Musician Kamasi Washington's Favorite Things
summary: A cane, a saxophone and one-of-a-kind robes are among his favorite possessions. "AS A KID, I imagined having my own arcade cabinet, like something out of Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous. This year, my label gave me Street Fighter Alpha 2 to celebrate the release of my album Heaven and Earth. Playing the game helps me clear my mind."

title: Barclays's Badly Timed Activist Might Be Good For its Board
summary: Activist Edward Bramson takes a fresh tilt at a board seat to aid his campaign for change. Barclays is having activist trouble again. summary: Resume Subscription. In reaction to hectic, over-scheduled lives burdened by 24-7 technology, a counter movement is emerging: the slow morning.

title: German Hacking Arrest Quells Fears Attack Was Foreign Backed
summary: Data belonging to nearly 1,000 people, including celebrities, were posted online. BERLIN-A German high-school student was behind a massive data theft that affected nearly 1,000 German politicians and other personalities and revived concerns over cybersecurity in a country with one of the world's toughest privacy laws.

title: The 1948 Plymouth That Defeated the North Dakota Winter
summary: Resume Subscription. Mary Motschenbacher, 68, a medical transcriptionist from Fargo, N.D., and her sister, Beth Boatz, a 67-year-old retired banker from Blaine, Minn., on their 1948 Plymouth, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: After 50 Long Days in Jail, Ghosn Is Sharp as He Prepares His Defense
summary: Former Nissan chairman is 'super-calm and rational' with his team, focusing on how to win his case. TOKYO-His cheeks are sunken and his once-robust frame has turned gaunt, but after 50 days in jail, Carlos Ghosn is still the hyperrational, results-oriented engineer who made it to the top of the auto industry. This time, instead of higher profits, the result he seeks is his own freedom and vindication.

title: Photos: Wicked Weather Has Nothing on This Car
summary: A pair of sisters show off the 1948 Plymouth they dubbed the Bomb as teenagers and restored after it sat unused for 44 years. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

summary: European legalization trend sparks a boom for entrepreneurs in 'the European California' as medical use grows. ATHENS-Christa Pappa quit her job as a research biologist last year to concentrate on her real career ambition: selling marijuana.

summary: PG&E, Wells Fargo and AZZ are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: North Korean Leader's Beijing Visit Underscores China's Pivotal Role
summary: Timing suggests Beijing could see North Korea as leverage in its trade dispute with U.S.. BEIJING-With denuclearization talks between Pyongyang and Washington at a standstill, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un turned this week to his country's longtime patron, China.

title: This Really Is the Next Revolution in TV Technology
summary: MicroLED is better looking, more efficient and more versatile than any previous display tech. Now all Samsung, Sony, LG and others have to do is figure out how to manufacture it affordably. LAS VEGAS-One of the most exciting things I've seen at this year's CES tech show was a man putting a TV together. It looked more like he was hanging photos. He'd grab square tiles off a pile, attach them to the wall, then screw a small plate up top. A moment later, the surface would spring to life. He'd attach another, and it would extend the picture. He built a TV one tile at a time, and it looked awesome.

title: Google to Lease Office Space in a Los Angeles Mall
summary: Search giant to move into space at Westside Pavilion, which will be redeveloped into 584,000 square-foot office campus. Google Inc. is planning to lease what is currently a mall in West Los Angeles, the latest deal in which former retail sites are now seen as appealing office locations for companies looking to attract and retain workers.

title: Foreigners Funded Houston Development to Get Green Cards. They Were Duped, SEC Says
summary: Immigration process known as EB-5 has come under increasing criticism in Congress. Scores of foreign investors in pursuit of U.S. green cards poured nearly $50 million into what they thought was going to be a giant senior housing, luxury residential and retail project in a booming suburb of Houston.

title: Tying American Stocks to the Rest of the World
summary: The U.S. premium to the rest of the world has fallen, but remains hefty. The great decoupling of the American stock markets from the rest of the world was the story last summer. title: WarnerMedia Puts Its Stake in New HQ Building Up for Sale, Before It Moves In
summary: Company follows in the footsteps of others looking to cash in on sale-leaseback agreements. WarnerMedia isn't expected to move into its future Manhattan headquarters until later this year, but it is already looking to unload its stake in the brand-new building.

title: Canada's Trade Deficit Widened In November
summary: Exports fell 2.9%, led by a 17.7% drop in crude-oil exports. OTTAWA-Canada's trade deficit more than doubled in November on a sharp drop in crude oil exports, as low oil prices continued to weigh on the country's energy sector.

summary: As U.S. trade negotiators meet with their Beijing counterparts, analysts are watching for even the smallest signs of progress. U.S. trade negotiators are in Beijing this week aiming to mend relations and rebalance trade. Also likely high on the agenda: calming volatile markets.

title: Pledges Made by Italy's Populist Government Come Up Against Economic Reality
summary: Populist parties came to power promising not to use public money to save troubled lenders, now they are offering to do so. ROME-Italy's populist government has offered to shore up an ailing bank with public money, in a sharp U-turn after attacking mainstream politicians for years for bailing out banks with taxpayers' money.

title: Two Sailors Missing, Another Is Killed in Hong Kong Tanker Explosion
summary: The Vietnamese registered Aulac Fortune was being refueled by a barge. At least one sailor has died and two others are missing after a large explosion on a tanker off the coast of Lamma Island in Hong Kong that was felt several miles away.

title: Volatility Signal Flashes Red, Even as Stocks Rebound
summary: The futures curve tracking Wall Street's 'fear gauge,' the VIX, remains inverted, despite recent gains in equities prices. The rebound in U.S. stocks since Friday hasn't convinced all investors that volatility in the market is over.

title: Nvidia Has Time to Get More Game
summary: Battered chip maker looks to expand market for new gaming processors. Nvidia needs time to get its videogaming business back on track. Fortunately for the chip maker, $76 billion buys a lot of it.

title: Tech That Will Change Your Life in 2019
summary: From delivery wagons and foldable phones to privacy crackdowns and corporate health tracking, the coming year will make good on some of the tech industry's biggest promises. There aren't many ways 2018 could have gone worse for the tech industry. It felt like every week, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and friends were apologizing for some major privacy blunder or platform manipulation. Self-driving cars proved they weren't ready to hit the road and Elon Musk nearly self-destructed on Twitter. Electric scooters swarmed cities only to be vandalized in droves. Tech-stock peaks gave way to market tumbles.

title: Small-Business Confidence in U.S. Economy Weakens
summary: Lobby's gauge of optimism falls for a fourth straight month. Small-business owners' confidence in the U.S. economy fell for the fourth consecutive month and their outlook on business conditions fell to the lowest level since late 2016, according to the National Federation of Independent Business.

title: Uber CEO Says Market Turmoil Won't Derail IPO Plans
summary: The ride-hailing giant is on track to list this year, Dara Khosrowshahi says in an interview. Uber Technologies Inc. Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi said market turbulence in the U.S. would be unlikely to affect the ride-hailing titan's plans for a public listing.

title: U.K. Finds a Faulty Shipping Safety Net for Brexit
summary: The government is racing the clock with contingency plans for a no-deal Brexit, but shipping companies say there are no easy solutions in supply chains. British policy makers are calling on the shipping industry to bail the country out from the mess that Brexit has become.

title: WeWork's Not Working for SoftBank Anymore
summary: The Japanese tech giant slashed a planned investment in the shared-workspace provider, after backers of its nearly $100 billion Vision fund got cold feet. SoftBank is trying to solve a hard problem. The Japanese tech conglomerate is scaling back a planned $16 billion investment into New York-based WeWork to just $2 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported. The retreat is down to the biggest backers of SoftBank's nearly $100 billion Vision Fund-sovereign-wealth funds from Saudi Arabia and Abu Dhabi-apparently cooling on the deal.

title: Chinese Bond Yields Hit Two-Year Low
summary: Resume Subscription. A weak economy has helped push Chinese bond yields to a two-year low. To some investors that looks overdone, given a likely surge in government debt issuance and a stabilizing stock market.

title: Samsung Echoes Apple's Gloomy Outlook as Tech Woes Deepen
summary: South Korean tech giant expects fourth quarter operating profit will fall 29%. SEOUL- Samsung Electronics Co. expects its fourth-quarter operating profit will decline 29%-surprise guidance that fell far below analysts' estimates-in the latest sign of challenges hitting the tech industry.

title: Clemson Routs Alabama to Win National Championship
summary: Led by freshman quarterback Trevor Lawrence and a stout defense, the Tigers claimed their second championship in three years. Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Shutdown Weighs on Federal Workers
summary: Employees who are set to miss a paycheck feel a pinch; 'state of being unsure'. Rusty Long is debating which bills to pay and which to hold off on, as he plans to miss his first paycheck on Friday, along with hundreds of thousands of other federal employees.

title: Kim Jong Un Visits China on His Birthday
summary: North Korean leader plans to stay in the country through Thursday. BEIJING-North Korean leader Kim Jong Un arrived in China, North Korea's main backer, as he sent mixed signals to the U.S. about his willingness to give up his nuclear weapons ahead of a possible second summit with President Trump.

title: Ghosn: 'I Have Been Wrongly Accused and Unfairly Detained'
summary: Former Nissan chief has been held in a Tokyo jail since Nov. 19. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn called the allegations against him "meritless and unsubstantiated," delivering a broadside against Japanese prosecutors in his first public statement since his arrest more than a month ago.

title: Nellie Liang Withdraws From Consideration for Fed Board Seat
summary: White House had nominated former Fed economist, in 2018, but Senate didn't act on nomination. WASHINGTON-Former Federal Reserve economist Nellie Liang, whom the Trump administration had nominated to serve on the central bank's board of governors, withdrew from consideration Monday, a casualty of opposition from the banking industry which feared she would stymie efforts to loosen financial regulation.

title: Businesses Report Glitches on Reopened Visa Website
summary: Lingering problems with site for applying for H-2B visas make companies fret they will lose out on workers for landscaping, restaurant and other seasonal work. WASHINGTON-Users complained of glitches and delays while applying for seasonal-work visas on a government website that reopened Monday after crashing on New Year's Day due to record demand.

title: Guatemalan President Expels Corruption Investigators
summary: Jimmy Morales, who was being probed for campaign violations, moves against unit after long showdown. MEXICO CITY-The government of Guatemalan President Jimmy Morales on Monday said it was unilaterally withdrawing from a United Nations-backed anticorruption commission and ordering its prosecutors and investigators to leave the country within 24 hours, exacerbating a political crisis.

title: Cuomo Vows to Codify Roe v. Wade Decision Into State Constitution
summary: Governor is pushing to pass both Reproductive Health Act and Contraceptive Care Act. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Monday that he will seek to codify Roe v. Wade, the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision recognizing a constitutional right to terminate pregnancy, into the state's Constitution.

title: Majority Preservation Act
summary: The first House Democratic bill aims to hamstring opponents.. House Democrats are up and running, and their first bill is instructive. Couched as an anti-corruption and good-government measure, it is really an attempt to silence or obstruct political opponents.

title: Amazon Is No. 1, for Now
summary: Not too long ago Apple was on top. The market is ruthless discipline.. One may wonder whether Jeff Bezos at the creation of Amazon thought the company would one day live up to its namesake river-which is to say, simply the biggest. Amazon, which began life online merchandising books and music, on Monday became the world's biggest company by market capitalization at a few nickles and dimes over $796 billion.

title: Brazil's Bolsonaro Is 2018's Biggest Winner
summary: Also: Italy's Salvini, Turkey's Erdogan, Syria's Assad, and Ethiopia's Abiy Ahmed.. Twenty eighteen was a disquieting year. Although capitalism continued to raise living standards almost everywhere, the geopolitical outlook dimmed. An antimarket backlash gained strength in many countries, and relations between the U.S. and China continued on a downward trajectory even as global defense spending hit a record high.

title: Trump Can't Afford to Lose
summary: The cost of defeat would be higher for President Trump than for Speaker Pelosi.. On Tuesday night, President Trump will deliver a prime-time address to the nation "on the Humanitarian and National Security crisis on our Southern border." It will be his first big address from the Oval Office, a signal that the president recognizes, at least on this issue, that to succeed he must reach beyond his base to rally the American people. He further promises to travel to the border Thursday to "meet with those on the front lines."

title: New Netflix CFO to Earn Almost Twice as Much as Predecessor
summary: Spencer Neumann set to receive total compensation of about $10 million, regulatory filing shows. Netflix Inc.'s new finance chief will make almost twice as much as its former CFO.

title: 'The Edge of Anarchy' Review: Blood On the Tracks
summary: The American Railway Union made a fatal strategic error during the 1894 Pullman strike when it voted to exclude African-Americans. Gregory Crouch reviews "The Edge of Anarchy" by Jack Kelly.. Tremendous technological, economic, political and social upheaval transformed America in the decades following the Civil War, and with that progress came much pain. Mechanization and mass immigration eliminated the labor scarcity that had benefited America's working class earlier in the 19th century. Postwar reconstruction, despite its initial promise, failed to deliver fair opportunity to former slaves and their children. In many industries, unfettered business interests established monopolies and trusts that raised prices, curried government concessions, and suppressed competition and wages.

title: Memories of Music's Prime Time
summary: TV themes from the 1970s and '80s are underappreciated.. The man behind two of the most memorable American songs of the past half-century died last month. Norman Gimbel composed lyrics for "The Girl From Ipanema" and "Killing Me Softly." But if you grew up in the 1970s and '80s, you may be more familiar with his less prestigious songs: the themes to "Happy Days" and "Laverne & Shirley."

title: Lesson From 2018: Republicans Must Deal With Climate Change
summary: My party will never earn the votes of millennials unless it gets serious about finding solutions.. As one of many Republican congressmen who just packed up their offices to make way for the Democratic majority, I've had time to reflect on what went wrong for the party. There are seismic political shifts under way on issues ranging from climate change to immigration to gun violence. If Republicans don't adapt by offering meaningful solutions, the midterm losses could be only the beginning.

title: Lying Prices Keep America Hooked on Spending
summary: When politicians hide the cost of government, 'free college' and 'Medicare for all' sound like bargains.. Margaret Thatcher famously said the problem with socialism is that you "always run out of other people's money." The trouble with resisting socialism is that until the money runs out, free-spending progressive policies are remarkably seductive. Their appeal comes from what economists call lying prices: advertised prices that don't reflect the full cost of what you're buying.

title: Tax Refunds Will Be Paid During Shutdown, White House Says
summary: New policy meant to 'mitigate the impact' of shutdown, Vice President Mike Pence says. WASHINGTON-The Internal Revenue Service will pay tax refunds even though the agency is subject to the federal government shutdown, after the Trump administration reversed a longstanding policy.

title: World Bank President Resigns to Join Investment Firm
summary: Early departure could reignite battle over who gets to pick leader of institution. WASHINGTON-World Bank President Jim Yong Kim unexpectedly announced his resignation on Monday, setting up a potential dispute between the U.S. and other member countries over selecting the next leader of the world's largest development-finance institution.

title: California to Flex Drug Purchasing Power
summary: New Governor, Gavin Newsom, announces health-policy changes including coverage for undocumented young adults. SACRAMENTO-California Gov. Gavin Newsom plans to bolster the state's power to negotiate prescription drug prices and expand health coverage for undocumented immigrants, as the Democrat aims to take the lead on policies at odds with those of the Trump administration.

title: Signs Point to Strong January for Stocks
summary: Not only is this month typically a good one for market, but this time it could benefit from the political calendar. Two consecutive sessions of stock gains erased the worst two-day start to a year since 2000. For investors who track seasonal patterns in markets, it also pointed major indexes in the right direction.

title: Starbucks CEO Reins In Predecessor's Ambitions: 'I'm Not Howard'
summary: Starbucks founder Howard Schultz had a vision of 1,000 new Reserve cafes selling premium-priced coffee; the new CEO says that was 'an aspiration'. Starbucks Corp. Chief Executive Kevin Johnson is scaling down some of longtime leader Howard Schultz's biggest initiatives as he seeks to revive sales in the chain's core coffee shops.

title: Notable & Quotable: Taxing Soda in Philly
summary: "This location has lost approximately 25 percent of its business over the last two years because of the tax...". From the website of Philadelphia's KYW, Jan. 2, 2019:
